hints_html:
Are there any obvious solutions to a homogeneous system?

What is the relationship between the rank of a matrix and the number of solutions?
hints_latex: Are there any obvious solutions to a homogeneous system?

What is the relationship between the rank of a matrix and the number of
solutions?
hints_raw:
Are there any obvious solutions to a homogeneous system?
What is the relationship between the rank of a matrix and the number of solutions?
question: A 08
sols_html:
Since the matrix is in upper triangular form, we can see immediately that it is of full rank, as none of the diagonal entries are 0. Then the system has exactly 1 solution. Clearly, the zero vector is a solution (to any homogenous system), so the only solution is the trivial solution

\[\begin{aligned} x = 0.\end{aligned}\]

We can work out the solution coordinate by coordinate using the augmented matrix:

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 7 & 7 & ... & 7 & | & 0\\ 0 & 2 & 7 & ... & 7 & | & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 3 & ... & 7 & | & 0\\ \vdots & \vdots & & \ddots & \vdots & | & \vdots\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & ... & 13 & | & 0\\ \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

The last row (13th) gives \(13x_{13} = 0\), so \(x_{13} = 0\). The 12th row gives \(12x_{12} + 7x_{13} = 0\), but \(x_{13} = 0\), so \(x_{12} = 0\). Similarly, we calculate \(x_{1} = x_{2} = \ldots = x_{10} = 0\), so the only solution is \(x = 0\).
sols_latex:
Since the matrix is in upper triangular form, we can see immediately
that it is of full rank, as none of the diagonal entries are 0. Then the
system has exactly 1 solution. Clearly, the zero vector is a solution
(to any homogenous system), so the only solution is the trivial
solution\begin{align*}
x = 0.
\end{align*}

We can work out the solution coordinate by coordinate using the
augmented matrix:

\begin{align*}
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 7 & 7 & ... & 7 & | &  0\\
0 & 2 & 7 & ... & 7 & | &  0\\
0 & 0 & 3 & ... & 7 & | &  0\\
\vdots & \vdots &  & \ddots & \vdots & | &  \vdots\\
0 & 0 & 0 & ... & 13 & | &  0\\
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

The last row (13th) gives $13x_{13} = 0$, so $x_{13} = 0$. The 12th row
gives $12x_{12} + 7x_{13} = 0$, but $x_{13} = 0$, so $x_{12} = 0$.
Similarly, we calculate $x_{1} = x_{2} = \ldots = x_{10} = 0$, so the
only solution is $x = 0$.
sols_raw:
Since the matrix is in upper triangular form, we can see immediately that it is of full rank, as none of the diagonal entries are 0. Then the system has exactly 1 solution. Clearly, the zero vector is a solution (to any homogenous system), so the only solution is the trivial solution: <math>x = 0 </math>.
We can work out the solution coordinate by coordinate using the augmented matrix:

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 7 & 7 & ... & 7 & | &  0\\
0 & 2 & 7 & ... & 7 & | &  0\\
0 & 0 & 3 & ... & 7 & | &  0\\
\vdots & \vdots &  & \ddots & \vdots & | &  \vdots\\
0 & 0 & 0 & ... & 13 & | &  0\\
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

The last row (13th) gives <math> 13x_{13} = 0 </math>, so <math> x_{13} = 0 </math>. The 12th row gives <math> 12x_{12} + 7x_{13} = 0 </math>, but <math> x_{13} = 0 </math>, so <math> x_{12} = 0 </math>. Similarly, we calculate <math> x_{1} = x_{2} = \ldots = x_{10} = 0 </math>, so the only solution is <math> x = 0 </math>.
statement_html:
Give all solutions to the homogeneous system \(Ax = 0\) where

\[\begin{aligned} A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 7 & 7 & ... & 7 \\ 0 & 2 & 7 & ... & 7 \\ 0 & 0 & 3 & ... & 7 \\ \vdots & \vdots & & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & ... & 13 \\ \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Justify that you have provided all solutions.
statement_raw:
Give '''all solutions''' to the homogeneous system <math>Ax = 0 </math> where

:<math>
A = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 7 & 7 & ... & 7 \\
0 & 2 & 7 & ... & 7 \\
0 & 0 & 3 & ... & 7 \\
\vdots & \vdots &  & \ddots & \vdots \\
0 & 0 & 0 & ... & 13 \\
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

Justify that you have provided all solutions.
